programs.description: The inflammasome-CXCL10 axis mediates CD8 T cell recruitment into glioblastoma tumors through IL-1β-dependent signaling. IL-1β activates IL-1R1 on glioblastoma cells to induce CXCL10 production, which serves as a potent chemoattractant for CD8 T cells. The AIM2 inflammasome triggers IL-1β cleavage and release, enabling this critical immune recruitment pathway. This program represents a potential therapeutic target for enhancing immune surveillance in immunologically cold tumors.

citations.notes: AIM2 inflammasome activation triggers caspase-1-mediated IL-1β cleavage in lung cancer cells
IL-1β induces CXCL10 expression by cancer cells, which mediates CD8 T cell recruitment

atomic_biological_processes.name: CD8 T cell infiltration and activation

citations.notes: CXCL10 production enables CD8 T cell accumulation and activation in tumor microenvironment

predicted_cellular_impact: Enhanced IL-1β signaling through IL-1R1 amplifies CXCL10 production
Increased CD8 T cell recruitment at tumor site
Potential for enhanced chemo-immunotherapy efficacy when IL-1β pathway is activated
programs.evidence_summary: The IL-1β/IL-1R1/CXCL10 axis is well-established in murine and human lung cancer models, with robust evidence that IL-1β triggers CXCL10 production in an autocrine manner, enabling CD8 T cell infiltration. Knockdown of CXCL10 completely abolishes the anti-tumor effects of chemo-immunotherapy combined with IL-1β, indicating this axis is necessary for immune control. The AIM2 inflammasome is widely expressed in cancer cell lines and elevated in cancer tissues compared to normal tissues, positioning it as a key upstream activator.

citations.notes: IL-1β essential for CXCL10 production and CD8 T cell recruitment; AIM2 inflammasome activation drives IL-1β release

programs.description: A multi-component inflammatory program involving interleukins (IL-6, IL-4R, LIF), acute-phase proteins (SAA1, SAA2, SAA4, PTX3), and associated signaling molecules that establish a pro-inflammatory tumor microenvironment. This program drives both immune cell recruitment and immune tolerance through redundant cytokine signaling. PTX3 participates in innate immunity through complement component interaction, while SAA proteins are markers of acute phase response and disease aggressiveness.

citations.notes: IL-6 functions in inflammation and B cell maturation
IL-6 encodes a cytokine with roles in inflammation and immune cell differentiation
PTX3 is an acute-phase protein involved in innate immunity and complement interaction
PTX3 interacts with C1q, factor H, ficolins, and mannan-binding lectin
SAA1 is an acute phase protein contributing to disease phenotypes
LIF is an IL-6 family cytokine with roles in stem cell signaling

predicted_cellular_impact: Establishment of pro-inflammatory tumor microenvironment through cytokine redundancy
Recruitment and polarization of immune effector cells
Creation of immune-tolerant niche through IL-4R and alternative activation pathways
Complement activation and regulation through PTX3
programs.evidence_summary: The inflammatory cytokine network is characterized by multiple cytokines (IL-6, IL-4R, LIF, PTX3) operating in concert to establish and maintain a pro-tumor microenvironment. IL-6 is a well-characterized inflammatory cytokine with established roles in B cell maturation and inflammation. SAA proteins are recognized as acute-phase markers enriched in aggressive disease states. PTX3 bridges innate immunity and complement activation. The redundancy of this network likely explains the robust inflammatory phenotype of glioblastomas and suggests that targeting single cytokines may be insufficient for therapeutic benefit.

citations.notes: IL-6 cytokine functions in inflammation and B cell maturation
PTX3 acute-phase protein involved in innate immunity
SAA1 as acute-phase protein marker of disease
Acute-phase protein signatures enriched in aggressive disease with immune response associations

programs.description: A comprehensive program coordinating matrix protein production (COL1A2, COL5A1, COL6A2, FN1), protease inhibition (SERPINE1), and matrix-associated factors (SMOC2, ANPEP, SPP1, ITGBL1) that collectively remodel the tumor microenvironment to facilitate glioblastoma cell invasion and migration. SERPINE1 (PAI-1) serves as a critical hub integrating protease activity with pro-invasive signaling. Spatial profiling reveals distinct ECM signatures in different tumor regions, suggesting coordinated ECM remodeling by specialized cell populations.

atomic_biological_processes.name: SERPINE1-mediated protease inhibition and invasion promotion

citations.notes: Enhanced PAI-1 expression associated with glioblastoma invasion
PAI-1 regulates glioblastoma invasion through protease inhibition
Spatial profiling identified nearly 400 ECM genes with unique expression patterns in different GBM cell populations
ECM-producing cell populations including endothelial cells and macrophages show spatially distinct signatures
ECM components establish spatial architecture in glioblastoma microenvironment

predicted_cellular_impact: Enhanced ECM deposition establishing pro-invasive microenvironment
Protease regulation through SERPINE1 enabling selective proteolysis
Spatial organization of tumor niches through distinct ECM signatures
Facilitation of vessel co-option and brain parenchyma infiltration
programs.evidence_summary: The extracellular matrix remodeling program is well-supported by spatial transcriptomic profiling revealing nearly 400 ECM genes with distinct expression signatures in different GBM populations. SERPINE1 (PAI-1) is directly implicated in glioblastoma invasion through multiple studies, with enhanced expression correlating with invasive phenotype. Collagen (COL1A2, COL5A1, COL6A2) and fibronectin (FN1) establish the physical scaffold of the tumor microenvironment. Matrix-associated proteins enable ECM-cell interactions supporting invasion. The spatial heterogeneity of ECM expression suggests that coordinated remodeling by multiple cell types creates permissive niches for tumor cell migration.

citations.notes: Single-cell spatial profiling identified ~400 ECM genes with distinct expression in GBM populations
PAI-1 associated with glioblastoma invasion
PAI-1 regulates glioblastoma invasion

programs.description: Pericyte depletion (70-80% loss in glioblastoma vasculature) drives a mesenchymal transition characterized by upregulation of stemness and plasticity markers (FOSL1, MET, GEM, GPC5). Pericytes normally orchestrate a tumor-restraining microenvironment through paracrine signaling; their loss promotes a hypoxia-associated mesenchymal-II (MES II) state with enhanced invasion and immune suppression. This program links vascular abnormality to tumor cell phenotypic transformation.

citations.notes: Pericytes identified as most active paracrine signaling hub within tumor parenchyma
Pericytes orchestrate tumor-restraining microenvironment through strategic positioning near blood vessels
NF1 regulates mesenchymal GBM plasticity through FOSL1
MES II cluster includes FOSL1, MET, CCN4, GRB10, SEMA3C genes associated with stemness and plasticity
MES II cells harbor hypoxia and stress-related genes including Hmox1, Tnc, Gdf15, Hspa9

predicted_cellular_impact: Loss of pericyte-mediated tumor suppression upon 70-80% pericyte depletion
Expansion of mesenchymal-II GBM cell state with stemness and invasion features
Increased alternatively activated macrophages and myeloid-derived suppressor cells
Enhanced vessel co-option and tumor cell infiltration along vasculature
Promotion of epithelial-mesenchymal transition programs
programs.evidence_summary: The pericyte loss program is extensively characterized through single-cell and spatial transcriptomic analysis of human GBM and mouse models with pericyte depletion (Pdgfb-ret/ret mice). Pericytes represent a dominant paracrine signaling hub despite their low relative abundance. Pericyte depletion correlates with accelerated tumor progression, shorter survival, increased hemorrhage, and necrosis. The mesenchymal-II state expanded in pericyte-depleted tumors expresses markers of stemness (FOSL1), survival signaling (MET), and invasion capability. The mechanistic link between pericyte loss and mesenchymal transition is supported by cell-cell communication analysis revealing increased signaling activity of mesenchymal transformation pathways.

citations.notes: Pericytes as most active signaling hub; depletion accelerates glioma progression
Pericyte depletion drives mesenchymal-II state with increased stemness and invasion markers
FOSL1 drives mesenchymal GBM plasticity
MES II marker genes include CCN4, GRB10, SEMA3C and hypoxia markers Hmox1, Tnc, Gdf15

programs.description: A transcription factor and signaling-driven program promoting epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) through EMP1, MET, AXL, FOSL1, and associated signaling molecules. EMP1 directly promotes EMT and extracellular matrix remodeling. MET activation through hepatocyte growth factor signaling drives mesenchymal phenotypic acquisition. CXCR4 expression associates with proneural-to-mesenchymal transition. This program is essential for glioblastoma invasiveness and therapeutic resistance.

citations.notes: EMP1 promotes epithelial-mesenchymal transition and K-RAS signaling; knockout reduces metastasis
Recruited macrophages express HGF reinforcing MET activation on GBM cells
MET included in MES II marker genes associated with plasticity and invasion
AXL involved in cell growth, migration, aggregation and anti-inflammation
FOSL1 AP-1 transcription factor regulates mesenchymal GBM plasticity

predicted_cellular_impact: Promotion of mesenchymal phenotype through EMP1 and FOSL1
Enhanced cell migration and invasion through MET and AXL activation
Reduced oxidative phosphorylation pathway activity characteristic of progenitor state
Increased K-RAS pathway activation supporting aggressive biology
Facilitation of therapeutic resistance through EMT-associated drug efflux mechanisms
programs.evidence_summary: The EMT promotion program is well-supported by studies of EMP1 in pancreatic cancer, where knockout reduced proliferation and metastasis while transcriptomic analysis revealed EMT and ECM remodeling promotion. EMP1 expression inversely correlates with oxidative phosphorylation pathways, indicating metabolic reprogramming toward glycolysis. MET activation through hepatocyte growth factor is confirmed in pericyte-depleted glioblastomas through single-cell analysis. AXL is established as a receptor tyrosine kinase mediating growth and invasion. FOSL1 is directly implicated in mesenchymal GBM plasticity through NF1 regulation. CXCR4 associates with proneural-to-mesenchymal transition in glioblastoma.

citations.notes: EMP1 promotes EMT and K-RAS signaling; knockout reduces proliferation and metastasis
FOSL1 regulates mesenchymal GBM plasticity
MET activation through HGF in pericyte-depleted tumors

programs.description: A metabolic program coordinating shifts from oxidative phosphorylation to aerobic glycolysis, lactate accumulation, and mitochondrial dysfunction in response to hypoxia. Core mechanisms involve HIF-1α-driven upregulation of glycolytic enzymes, mitochondrial fragmentation affecting OXPHOS efficiency, and lactate utilization as both energy source and signaling molecule. Genes including NDRG1, GPD1, HAP1, DHRS3, KLF5, and BAG3 support this metabolic transition.

citations.notes: HIF-1α binds glycolysis-related genes (Glut1, HK2, LDHA, PKM2) enhancing glycolytic activity
SUCLG2 knockdown reduces lactate metabolism; lactate peak significantly higher in tumor core
L-lactate promotes GBM malignant progression; treatment upregulates proliferation markers PCNA, cyclin D1, Bcl-2
SUCLG2 knockdown inhibits mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation; SUCLG2-LMNA-MFN1 pathway controls fusion/fragmentation
Mitochondrial OXPHOS complex proteins (SDHB, ND1, ATP5A) reduced in metabolic stress
Mitochondrial fusion protein MFN1 degradation drives fragmentation and apoptosis

predicted_cellular_impact: Enhanced glucose uptake and glycolytic flux in response to hypoxia
Accumulation of lactate to ~40mM in tumor core with multiple signaling roles
Mitochondrial fragmentation reducing OXPHOS efficiency
Sustained cell survival under glucose scarcity through lactate utilization (10-15mM rescues viability)
Metabolic inflexibility enabling selective targeting through metabolic inhibitors
programs.evidence_summary: The metabolic reprogramming program is extensively characterized through multiple integrated approaches including MR spectroscopy showing elevated lactate in tumor core, transcriptomic analysis of SUCLG2-mediated metabolic control, and functional studies demonstrating lactate rescue of glioblastoma viability under glucose scarcity. Lactate accumulates to approximately 40mM in tumors, with 10-15mM concentrations sufficient to reverse loss of cell viability under low-glucose conditions. HIF-1α-driven glycolytic upregulation is a well-established hypoxic response. Mitochondrial fragmentation through MFN1 degradation is confirmed as a mechanism of metabolic restriction in SUCLG2-knockdown cells. Lactate treatment directly upregulates proliferation markers and anti-apoptotic proteins.

citations.notes: SUCLG2 controls mitochondrial metabolism and lactate production in GBM
Lactate metabolism drives GBM progression; HIF-1α regulates glycolytic genes
HIF-1α regulates Glut1, HK2, LDHA, PKM2; SUCLG2-LMNA-MFN1 axis controls metabolism

programs.description: A bidirectional crosstalk program between endoplasmic reticulum stress and lipid metabolism that maintains proteostasis under metabolic challenge. Through the unfolded protein response (UPR), ER stress reprograms lipid synthesis, oxidation, and storage to sustain energy balance and membrane integrity. Dysregulated lipid accumulation conversely disrupts ER homeostasis, creating feedback loops between metabolic and proteostatic imbalance. Genes including BAG3, TNFAIP3, TNFAIP2, and implicitly ERN1 participate in this adaptive network.

citations.notes: UPR reprograms lipid synthesis, oxidation, storage through ER stress sensing
ER stress couples with lipid metabolism in bidirectional regulatory network
Ubiquitin-proteasome system and autophagy cooperate with UPR to fine-tune adaptive balance
ER stress central to adaptive response maintaining proteostasis under metabolic challenge

predicted_cellular_impact: Maintenance of proteostasis under metabolic and environmental stress
Coupling of protein quality control with lipid remodeling
Enhanced tumor survival through adaptive stress response
Creation of feedback loops enabling metabolic flexibility
Potential therapeutic vulnerability through combined lipid and UPR targeting
programs.evidence_summary: The ER stress-lipid metabolism coupling program is well-characterized through systems approaches examining cancer cell adaptation. ER stress is positioned as a central adaptive response maintaining protein quality control under diverse challenges. The UPR actively reprograms lipid metabolism, coupling protein folding with bioenergetic and biosynthetic adaptation. Dysregulated lipid accumulation disrupts ER homeostasis, creating bidirectional feedback. BAG3 functions as a cochaperone supporting stress-induced autophagy and protein quality control. TNFAIP3 (A20) provides negative feedback on inflammatory signaling while promoting cell survival. The redundancy and feedback nature of this network underlies the robustness of glioblastoma adaptation to metabolic stress.

citations.notes: Bidirectional crosstalk between ER stress and lipid metabolism maintains tumor adaptation and survival
UPR involves ATF4, ATF6, IRE1A, PERK and CHOP transcription factors

programs.description: A multi-layered immune evasion program combining checkpoint ligand expression (CD274/PD-L1), tryptophan depletion (IDO1), complement inhibition (CFH), and anti-apoptotic signaling (FAS, BIRC3) to establish an immunosuppressive microenvironment. CD274 engagement with PD-1 on T cells blocks activation; IDO1 depletes tryptophan enabling regulatory T cell differentiation; CFH inhibits complement cascade. This program directly opposes anti-tumor immunity and represents key therapeutic targets.

citations.notes: CD274 (PD-L1) immunosuppressive checkpoint protein integrated with tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes in glioma characterization
IDO1 depletes tryptophan generating kynurenine enabling regulatory T cell differentiation
CFH is complement factor regulating cascade initiation
FAS death receptor involvement in apoptosis

predicted_cellular_impact: Blockade of T cell activation through PD-L1/PD-1 engagement
Tryptophan depletion enabling regulatory T cell differentiation and CD8 T cell exhaustion
Resistance to complement-mediated lysis through CFH-mediated cascade inhibition
Suppression of death receptor-mediated apoptosis
Creation of immunologically cold tumor resistant to checkpoint inhibitors alone
programs.evidence_summary: The immune checkpoint evasion program combines multiple redundant mechanisms ensuring robust immune evasion. CD274 (PD-L1) is well-established as an immunosuppressive checkpoint with levels correlating with glioma microenvironment characterization. IDO1 depletes tryptophan and generates kynurenine, enabling regulatory T cell differentiation and CD8 T cell exhaustion through GCN2 kinase activation. CFH is a negative regulator of complement cascade, enabling tumor escape from complement-mediated lysis. FAS death receptor and BIRC3 anti-apoptotic proteins provide redundant survival signals. The redundancy of immune evasion mechanisms (PD-L1, IDO1, complement inhibition) explains the limited efficacy of single-agent checkpoint inhibitors and suggests need for combination approaches.

citations.notes: CD274 (PD-L1) checkpoint protein in glioma microenvironment
IDO1 tryptophan depletion enables regulatory T cell differentiation
Trispecific antibody targeting CD3, B7H3, PDL1 to redirect T cells while mitigating immunosuppression

programs.description: A vascular support program coordinating growth factor signaling (VEGFA, ANGPTL4), chemokine-mediated leukocyte recruitment (CXCL8, CXCL2, CXCL14), and adhesion molecule expression (ICAM1) to establish and maintain abnormal tumor vasculature. VEGFA drives endothelial proliferation; ANGPTL4 destabilizes vascular barriers facilitating infiltration; chemokines recruit immune suppressive myeloid cells; ICAM1 mediates leukocyte recruitment and adhesion.

citations.notes: VEGFA promotes angiogenic properties of human glioblastoma cells
ANGPTL4 and VEGF synergistically destabilize retinal vascular barrier
ANGPTL4 acts synergistically with VEGF to destabilize vascular barriers
CXCL8 secreted by macrophages induces PD-L1(+) macrophages in immunosuppressive microenvironment
High ICAM1 expression associated with glioblastoma
Glioblastoma vasculature characterized by microvascular proliferation and functional abnormality

predicted_cellular_impact: Enhanced endothelial cell proliferation driving microvascular proliferation characteristic of GBM
Vascular barrier destabilization facilitating tumor cell infiltration
Recruitment of immunosuppressive myeloid cells through chemokine signaling
Facilitation of tumor cell migration along blood vessels
Disruption of blood-brain barrier enabling peripheral immune cell entry
programs.evidence_summary: The angiogenesis program is well-supported by established roles of VEGFA in glioblastoma angiogenesis and vascular proliferation. ANGPTL4 is documented to synergize with VEGF in barrier destabilization, enabling tumor cell infiltration. CXCL8 is shown to induce immunosuppressive macrophage polarization, linking angiogenic and immune suppressive programs. ICAM1 is highly expressed in glioblastoma and regulates leukocyte recruitment. The convergence of pro-angiogenic signals (VEGFA, ANGPTL4), chemotactic factors (CXCL8, CXCL2), and adhesion molecules (ICAM1) creates an interconnected program supporting both vascular abnormality and immune cell infiltration.

citations.notes: VEGFA promotes angiogenic properties in glioblastoma
ANGPTL4 and VEGF synergistically destabilize vascular barriers
CXCL8 induces immunosuppressive macrophage polarization
High ICAM1 associated with glioblastoma

programs.description: An integrated survival program employing multiple anti-apoptotic mechanisms including inhibitors of apoptosis (BIRC3), negative feedback regulators of inflammatory signaling (TNFAIP3, TNFAIP2), death receptor signaling (FAS), and protein quality control (BAG3). BIRC3 directly inhibits caspases; TNFAIP3 (A20) provides negative feedback on NF-κB; TNFAIP2 suppresses TNF signaling; BAG3 supports stress-induced autophagy and survival. This program enables glioblastoma cell survival under apoptotic pressure.

citations.notes: BIRC3 encodes inhibitor of apoptosis suppressing caspase activation
TNFAIP3 (A20) induced by TNF-alpha and NF-κB providing negative feedback limiting inflammatory signaling
TNFAIP2 suppresses TNF signaling pathways

atomic_biological_processes.name: stress-induced autophagy and protein quality control

citations.notes: BAG3 functions as cochaperone supporting stress-induced autophagy enabling survival

predicted_cellular_impact: Direct caspase inhibition preventing apoptotic cascade initiation
Negative feedback limiting inflammatory-induced apoptosis
Enhanced protein quality control and selective autophagy
Reduced death receptor-mediated apoptosis
Enhanced survival under metabolic and proteostatic stress
programs.evidence_summary: The anti-apoptotic program employs redundant survival mechanisms ensuring robust protection from apoptotic stimuli. BIRC3 is a canonical inhibitor of apoptosis directly suppressing caspase activation. TNFAIP3 (A20) provides well-characterized negative feedback on NF-κB signaling while simultaneously promoting cell survival, suggesting it functions as a molecular switch preventing excessive inflammation-induced apoptosis. TNFAIP2 similarly suppresses TNF signaling. BAG3 is a cochaperone supporting stress-induced autophagy as an adaptive response enabling cell survival. The convergence of caspase inhibition, inflammatory signal suppression, and protein quality control creates robust protection from apoptosis.

citations.notes: BIRC3 inhibitor of apoptosis suppressing caspase activation
TNFAIP3 negative feedback on NF-κB and inflammatory signaling
BAG3 supports stress-induced autophagy and tumor survival

clustering_basis: pathway integration from search results and NCBI gene records
co-expression in glioblastoma tumor microenvironment based on single-cell transcriptomics
functional validation in multiple experimental systems
mechanistic studies linking genes to phenotypic outcomes
method.notes: Programs identified through systematic integration of literature evidence establishing functional relationships between input genes and biological processes. Strong support for IL-1β-CXCL10 axis, pericyte-mesenchymal transition coupling, SERPINE1-invasion linkage, and metabolic-immunological integration. Prioritized programs with multiple input genes functioning in same pathway and strong experimental support. Programs ranked by significance based on supporting genes, citation density, and contextual relevance to malignant glioblastoma.
